channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Ivan Dorn, a pop star was born in Russia and grew up in Ukraine, promoted friendship between the two nations for years. Now, he has cut ties with Moscow and is raising money to help Ukrainians in peril. https://t.co/TifNREbIVW
Breaking News: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka has agreed to resign, an ally said, after protesters, furious over economic turmoil, stormed his home. https://t.co/xAt856Lvtq

"I’m tired of this separation of church and state junk," Rep. Lauren Boebert, a Republican from Colorado, said to applause from congregants in a church. She's part of a wave of right-wing politicians aiming to promote Christian power in America. https://t.co/yYgMdPbXrv

As President Biden insists he plans to run for a second term, his age has increasingly become an uncomfortable issue for him and his party. Polls show many Americans consider him too old, and some Democratic strategists do not think he should run again. https://t.co/OxncGGcbL4

Despite major policy disagreements, Democratic donors are backing Liz Cheney in Wyoming’s upcoming Republican primary because of her role on the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack. https://t.co/tVrX1gCWEO

President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka agreed to step down after what appeared to be one of the largest protests yet, following months of demonstrations fueled by the nation’s economic crisis. https://t.co/uhalnevBtD https://t.co/wIOMB2MeU3

More than 1,000 people gathered in front of the White House, with hundreds risking arrest by sitting at the building’s gates, as they urged President Biden to take more federal action to protect abortion rights. https://t.co/cbpvC7AHga https://t.co/ocUwmJh9IO

Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona signed a measure into law that makes it illegal for people to record videos within eight feet of police activity. Civil rights and news media organizations have objected to the law as a violation of free speech protections. https://t.co/Zv0s0Pydml

A New York Times investigation into a Bronx apartment fire in January that killed 17 people found that the deaths were preventable. Deadly smoke filled all 19 stories when the fire safety system failed disastrously. https://t.co/b0DeCt4U4Q

Hundreds of people lined up at a makeshift memorial in Nara, Japan, to pay their respects to Shinzo Abe, the country’s longest serving prime minister. He was assassinated there on Friday while speaking at a political rally. https://t.co/pH9UTtm1OC https://t.co/JpBp2Z2gyS

Breaking News: Elena Rybakina, a Russian-born player representing Kazakhstan, beat Ons Jabeur of Tunisia in three sets to win the Wimbledon singles title. https://t.co/QJ4pcJnpCy https://t.co/aUu89WAIzH

The JROTC program has often become a place where retired military officers prey on teenage students, a New York Times investigation found. In the past five years, at least 33 instructors were criminally charged with sexual misconduct involving students. https://t.co/wJU32nl5Br https://t.co/ivgfOOEgcE

Demonstrators entered the residence of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka on Saturday, amid large protests over the country’s economic crisis. The country's political leaders have asked him to step down. https://t.co/R2N2OQLhZ9 https://t.co/3tgR68dfDU

The prime minister of Sri Lanka announced that he will quit. President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has been asked by the country’s political leaders to also step down after months of protests accusing him of running the economy into the ground. https://t.co/yMTAPxaWCv

Memory decline is not inevitable with aging, neuroscientist Dr. Richard Restak argues in his latest book. Here are some of his tips for developing and maintaining a healthy memory. https://t.co/QyFr9cuUiy
Tin Chin and Mo Lin were inseparable at the Brooklyn homeless shelter where they met. But one of the men wasn’t who he seemed to be. https://t.co/cI1Q151BHw

Breaking News: Protesters in Sri Lanka entered the president’s home as thousands descended on the capital amid fury over a devastating economic crisis.
https://t.co/V2uiX1GnyD

A judge in Britain sided with Prince Harry in his defamation suit against the tabloid newspaper, The Mail on Sunday. The ruling, part of an initial phase of Harry's libel case, found parts of the article to be defamatory. https://t.co/KDku3YyG6z

A new wave of right-wing candidates is explicitly aiming to promote Christian power in America, with many mixing religious fervor with conspiracy theories, and even calling for the end of the separation of church and state. https://t.co/wFLMWZ9V3J

If LeBron James, instead of Brittney Griner, were in custody, wouldn't the outcry be louder? Male athletes benefit from a sports ecosystem that gives them more attention and bigger fame, @kurtstreeter writes. https://t.co/ROycIfqHgN

In Opinion
"It offends me to see sanctimonious public prayer in any circumstance — but a coach holding his players hostage while an audience watches his piety makes my skin crawl," writes Anne Lamott, a novelist, in a guest essay. https://t.co/P85uBxDsrW
In a game called GeoGuessr, competitors try to pinpoint where in the world a Google Street View image has been taken. Some can do it in seconds. https://t.co/OM8iLsw06g

The U.S. women’s national soccer team qualified for the 2023 Women’s World Cup after a 5-0 victory over Jamaica in a regional championship. The team will now play to secure a place in the Paris Olympics. https://t.co/Trre5UUqB3 https://t.co/g3ZPfxmla4
Tony Sirico, the actor who played Paulie Walnuts in the hit HBO series “The Sopranos,” has died at 79. https://t.co/kUGPOyQc90

A 41-year-old man used a “homemade” gun to assassinate Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister of Japan, police officials said. The man was arrested and charged with murder. https://t.co/LQg3EyTGEn https://t.co/DaXNVPQx4E
Breaking News: Four Border Patrol agents are facing disciplinary action over their aggressive treatment of migrants at the border last year. https://t.co/JqzM5y28z8

Elon Musk said on Friday that he planned to terminate his blockbuster $44 billion deal to buy Twitter, after publicly indicating over months that he was dissatisfied with the agreement. https://t.co/dClbWNxhqW https://t.co/ps6AymA1vX

President Biden issued an order aiming to protect access to abortion medication and emergency contraception — but details on how those goals would be accomplished were not outlined. https://t.co/PJey7MNMpI https://t.co/suQkMs02kZ

"This is America," President Biden said after awarding the Presidential Medal of Freedom to 17 people. The recipients included Simone Biles, Denzel Washington and former Senator John McCain, who was honored posthumously. https://t.co/ZD7bABLKl6
Canadians will recognize this recipe: butter tarts. Each bite delivers three textures: flaky crust, chewy top, gooey center. https://t.co/aakrltetir https://t.co/Cxzh8KOgVm

A person in Japan must pass 12 steps before purchasing a firearm, including a written exam and a doctor's sign-off on their mental and physical health. Gun violence is almost unheard of in Japan, making Shinzo Abe's assassination even harder to fathom. https://t.co/2si1OvMY0x
Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan on Friday called the fatal shooting of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe an "act of cowardly barbarism." https://t.co/FEkYw6Xo46 https://t.co/trp0qQMLGY

Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister, was assassinated as he gave a speech in the western city of Nara. A 41-year-old suspect was arrested and a crude weapon was retrieved, the police said.
Here’s a look at the scene of the attack. https://t.co/nSRBVbmFsC https://t.co/VNbe1uok4s
The symptoms of coronavirus subvariants BA.4 and BA.5 are similar to those of earlier versions of Omicron, experts said. https://t.co/WIkKYeRt9m https://t.co/hYTgcAdHYN

In Opinion
“Johnson’s career is ending, at least for now, the way Trump’s should have ended — with public revulsion leading his own party to oust him," writes Michelle Goldberg of the British prime minister. https://t.co/uBDVUCSvpk
Breaking News: The Wisconsin Supreme Court prohibited the use of most drop boxes for absentee ballots, a win for Republicans who want to limit voting access in urban areas. https://t.co/nOMoD5z1t8

The attack on former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was especially shocking since gun violence is extremely rare in the country. Japan’s firearms law states that, in principle, firearms are not permitted. https://t.co/OajvZmScnY

President Biden said he was “stunned, outraged and deeply saddened by the news that my friend Abe Shinzo, former prime minister of Japan, was shot and killed while campaigning. This is a tragedy for Japan and for all who knew him.” https://t.co/VKtANf3QDH https://t.co/j1B1axKWOL
How many children does Elon Musk have? News reported on Wednesday brought the known total to nine. https://t.co/5GEE1TJyWI

Mourners placed flowers near the site where Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister, was assassinated in the city of Nara.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/ng1JsLS5vz https://t.co/wYxe3z4nG2

The assassination of Shinzo Abe rattled Japan and its sense of identity as a peaceful country where violent crime is rare.
“I’m shocked by this,” one woman said. “The shooting part is confusing. There are guns? In Japan?” https://t.co/slQoY2gKMd

Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan condemned the killing of Shinzo Abe and praised the former leader’s achievements in peace and stability in both Japan and the world. https://t.co/0kdbVMQJsG https://t.co/ELPgrJIRGj

Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest-serving prime minister, died on Friday after being shot. He was 67.
He helped pull his country out of economic malaise, but fell short of his most cherished goal: making Japan a normalized military power. https://t.co/rq4J0Nj1l5 https://t.co/DIdGf4gcow

Akie Abe, the wife of Shinzo Abe, arrived at the hospital where Japan's former prime minister was being treated after he was shot, according to local media.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/rGA7PSuot1 https://t.co/DQTQJZYDZO
Breaking News: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest-serving prime minister, was assassinated during a public speech. He was 67. A suspect was arrested. https://t.co/m82R4CByyF https://t.co/9nosZ1Jpcp

The brother of Shinzo Abe and Japan's defense minister, Nobuo Kishi, said of the attack on Abe: "Especially suppression of free speech should not be allowed in the midst of the upper house election."
"We pray for his definite recovery." https://t.co/kxweVRs3IM https://t.co/QazQ9yUm9j
Brad Pitt has said he might have prosopagnosia, a rare neurological disorder commonly referred to as face blindness. Here’s what to know about the condition. https://t.co/aAXb55NBwq

Memory decline is not inevitable with aging, neuroscientist Dr. Richard Restak argues in his latest book. Here are some of his tips for developing and maintaining a healthy memory. https://t.co/iRePACBvJ9

Videos shared on social media showed the scene moments after Shinzo Abe, Japan's former leader, was shot at a junction in the city of Nara.
This video includes scenes of graphic violence: https://t.co/7MxzFjSOkf https://t.co/kSUut1WX5a

Breaking News: Shinzo Abe, Japan's former leader, is in critical condition after being shot, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said. Appearing emotional, he called the shooting a "heinous act."
Follow live updates. https://t.co/lYB9xKtNh2 https://t.co/fKCNA6gckO
